_prev_prog_3.Description: DeWafelbakkers is a Bakery/Cold storage facility. This facility falls under the NAICS code 424420. Our safety information was last reviewed and updated 6/13/2017 (Safety meetings are conducted every month). We are subject to the handling codes of the National Fire Protection Association, American National Standards Institute, and the American Society of Mechanical Engineers standards. These standards, and all applicable OSHA standards have been implemented here through written manuals by Environmental Services Group, Inc. The most recent hazard review and update conducted at this facility was July 5, 2017 and corrections/recommendations should be completed by July 5, 2022. To prevent /limit releases, this facility uses vents, relief valves, check valves, manual valve shutoffs, alarms and procedures, emergency air supply, emergency power backup, and grounding equipment. Operating and training procedures were reviewed on June 13, 2017. The employees of DeWafelbakkers are trained in the classroom and by on-the -job training. This training is completed with competency test including demonstration, and observation. The maintenance procedures are reviewed by operators on a regularly basis to ensure proper operation of the refrigeration system. The last time they were reviewed was on June 13, 2017.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



In this Bakery/cold storage facility, we handle anhydrous ammonia with is considered 

hazardous by EPA.  The same properties that makes anhydrous ammonia valuable as a cold 

storage refrigerant chemical, also makes it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in 

handling anhydrous ammonia. Overall, the prevention of unnecessary human exposure, reducing 

the threat to our own personal health as well as our co-worker, and reducing the threat to nearby 

members of the community is the main goal of incorporating this risk management plan into our 

daily operations.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and 

regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle anhydrous ammonia 

combined with the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, with the safe handling 

procedures that we utilize, and the training of our personnel.  



Our emergency action plan was developed with the assistance of Environmental Services 

Group, Inc.  The emergency action plan includes procedures for notification of Pulaski 

County 911 System for 911 call-out to affected responding agencies, the North Little Rock 

Fire Department, then the notification of Terry Washburn Plant Engineer @ 501-791-3320 

(24 Hours), the North Little Rock Fire Department and North Little Rock Police 

Department will help to notify and evacuate any potentially affected neighbors by utilizing 

vehicles with PA mounted announcing systems.  The 911 System will also notify Pulaski 

County LEPC.  



The primary purpose of this facility is to cool and/or freeze storage compartments by utilizing 

anhydrous ammonia. Anhydrous ammonia is stored in storage vessels located at the north 

side of the facility.  Anhydrous ammonia is fed into the cooling system for cold storage.  

The system is a two-stage pump re-circulated ammonia refrigeration system.  The Hi Stage 

Compressor serves the Freezer, Coolers, and the Lo Stage Comp

ressor discharge loads.  

The Lo Stage system serves the freezer.  Other associated systems are the thermosyphon oil 

cooling for the compressors, liquid feed make up, purge, and condensing system.  Note:  

The system flow diagram and control wiring diagrams should be used in conjunction with 

this description. Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized 

management personnel, and authorized contractors.  



The regulated substance handled at the 10000 Crystal Hill Rd. location is anhydrous ammonia.  

The maximum amount of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored at this plant is 24,230 pounds.  

This amount is an aggregate found in the storage vessel, as well as the entire cold storage system.





The worst-case scenario is failure of my largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount 

allowed would release 18,573 pounds of anhydrous ammonia from the 10000 Crystal Hill Rd. 

Passive mitigation was considered for this scenario. It is assumed that the entire contents are 

released as vapor.  The distance to the endpoint of 0.14 mg/l for the worst-case scenario is 1.7 

miles.  This location is classified as urban due to the amount of obstructions around the 

site.



An alternative scenario was determined for this facility. An estimation, based on the operational 

flow rate, cross section area of pipe, operational pressure of pipe, and the change in elevation of 

the pipe. Using the RMP Comp software, a release from this type of pipe would result in a 

release of approximately 57.7 pounds per minute released into the atmosphere.  This release 

was due to relief valve lifting for 30 minutes. This amount of vapor ammonia release would result in a 

distance to endpoint of approximately 0.1 miles.  



This cold storage facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all 

applicable state codes and regulations. 



Our emergency action plan was developed with the assistance of Environmental

Services 

Group, Inc.  We have discussed this program with the the North Little 

Rock Police Department, as well as the North Little Rock Fire Department. 



The cold storage system at this facility was constructed in 1994. This facility is striving to be in 

compliance with all applicable regulations applicable to this facility.
